Options: A: Decreased anti-dsDNA antibodies	B: Decreased complement levels	C: Increased anti-centromere antibodies	D: Increased anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies	E: Increased anti-topoisomerase antibodies
B

Increased anti-dsDNA antibodies are most likely to be seen in this patient because they are a marker for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and brain. The symptoms of SLE can vary widely from person to person. In this patient, the presence of bilateral joint pain, fatigue, subjective fever, and sunburn on the face suggests that she may have SLE. The sunburn is particularly concerning because it is a sign of photosensitivity, which is common in SLE. The other answer choices are not as likely to be seen in this patient because they are markers for other autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis (anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies), scleroderma (anti-centromere antibodies), and Sjögren's syndrome (anti-topoisomerase antibodies). Therefore, the answer is: A

C: Increased anti-centromere antibodies. Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, also known as CREST syndrome. CREST is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the skin, but can also involve other organs, such as the joints, lungs, and kidneys. The symptoms of CREST can include skin thickening, joint pain, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, telangiectasias, and calcinosis. Anti-centromere antibodies are found in approximately 60-70% of patients with CREST syndrome. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient is a young woman with fatigue, subjective fever, malar rash, and bilateral joint pain. These are all symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is an autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks the body's own tissues and organs. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are commonly seen in patients with SLE. Therefore, the answer is: A

Increased anti-dsDNA antibodies. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body. The most common symptoms of SLE are joint pain, skin rashes, and fatigue. SLE is more common in women than in men. It is also more common in people of African, Hispanic, and Asian descent. The diagnosis of SLE is based on the patient's symptoms and a physical examination. Blood tests can also be used to help diagnose SLE. One of the blood tests that is often used to diagnose SLE is the anti-dsDNA antibody test. A positive anti-dsDNA antibody test is a strong indicator that a person has SLE. Therefore, the answer is: A

Increased anti-dsDNA antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and brain. The patient has a sunburn on her face, which is a common symptom of SLE. She also has bilateral joint pain, which is another common symptom of SLE. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week. She has been having dull right-side abdominal pain during this period. She has nausea. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and an oral contraceptive. She appears ill. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. On examination, the liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 5%
Serum
Glucose 79 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L
AST 69 U/L
ALT 100 U/L
A right upper quadrant ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
Options: A: Discontinue the oral contraceptive	B: Obtain hepatoiminodiacetic acid scan	C: Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography	D: Administer metronidazole	E: Perform percutaneous drainage
"
E

The ultrasound shows cholelithiasis with cholecystitis. The patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, nausea, and an elevated white blood cell count. These findings are consistent with acute cholecystitis. The next step is to administer metronidazole, which is an antibiotic that is effective against anaerobic bacteria, which are commonly found in the bile. Therefore, the answer is: D

The ultrasound shows gallstones and cholecystitis. The patient has right-side abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus, which is a risk factor for cholecystitis. The next step is to administer metronidazole to treat the cholecystitis. Therefore, the answer is: D

The ultrasound shows a dilated common bile duct and gallbladder distended with gallstones. The patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. These findings suggest acute cholecystitis. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer metronidazole, which is an antibiotic that is effective against anaerobic bacteria, which are commonly found in the biliary tract. Therefore, the answer is: D

The ultrasound shows a cholelithiasis. The patient is febrile, has right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, and has leukocytosis. The liver is enlarged and tender. The laboratory studies show elevated alkaline phosphatase, AST, and ALT. This suggests acute cholecystitis. The next step is to perform percutaneous drainage to relieve the inflammation and prevent complications. Therefore, the answer is: E

The ultrasound shows a dilated gallbladder without evidence of stones. The patient has right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. She has a palpable liver and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. These findings are consistent with cholangitis. The patient is a woman of child-bearing age taking an oral contraceptive. Oral contraceptives can increase the risk of cholecystitis and cholangitis. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to discontinue the oral contraceptive. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed during breakfast that the left side of his face was drooping. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He drinks one glass of wine daily. He is alert and oriented to time, place and person. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. There is drooping of the left side of the face. Muscle strength is decreased in the left upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left side. Speech is dysarthric. There is a bruit on the right side of the neck. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: MRI of the brain	B: Lumbar puncture	C: Duplex ultrasonography of the neck	D: Cerebral angiography	E: CT scan of the head
E

The patient has a sudden onset of left-sided weakness, which suggests an acute cerebrovascular event. The most appropriate next step in management is CT scan of the head, which can identify the presence of a hemorrhage or infarction and help to determine the underlying cause of the stroke. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient has sudden onset of facial droop, dysarthria, and left-sided weakness. These findings suggest a stroke. The patient has a bruit on the right side of the neck, which suggests carotid artery stenosis. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is the most appropriate next step in management because it can provide information about the structure and function of the carotid arteries, including the presence and severity of stenosis. This information can help to determine the need for further treatment, such as carotid endarterectomy or stenting. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has sudden onset of left-sided facial drooping, weakness of the left upper and lower extremities, and dysarthria. He has a bruit on the right side of the neck. These findings suggest a cerebrovascular accident (CVA) due to carotid artery stenosis. The most appropriate next step in management is to obtain duplex ultrasonography of the neck to assess the carotid arteries and determine the extent of the stenosis. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has sudden onset of facial droop, weakness in the left upper and lower extremities, and an extensor plantar response on the left side. These findings suggest a stroke. The next step is to obtain a CT scan of the head to confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of stroke (ischemic or hemorrhagic). Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient has sudden-onset left-sided weakness and dysarthria. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. The bruit on the right side of the neck suggests carotid artery stenosis. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is the most appropriate next step in management because it can provide information about the structure and blood flow in the carotid arteries, including the presence of stenosis or plaque. This information can help to determine the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms and guide further management. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother after she found him somnolent at home next to multiple open pill bottles. The boy had seemingly opened several different pill bottles that were in a cabinet in his parent’s bathroom. The mother has brought the empty bottles to the emergency room, and they include aspirin, metoprolol, acetaminophen, levothyroxine, and lorazepam. The boy has no past medical history and takes no medications. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 28/min. On exam, the boy is lethargic but responsive. He appears to be grasping at his ears and swaying from side-to-side when attempting to ambulate. He vomited once in the emergency room. Which of the following arterial blood gas readings is most likely to be found in this patient?
Options: A: pH 7.29, PCO2 47 mmHg, and HCO3- 22 mEq/L	B: pH 7.35, PCO2 29 mmHg, and HCO3- 15 mEq/L	C: pH 7.36, PCO2 22 mmHg, and HCO3- 16 mEq/L	D: pH 7.47, PCO2 41 mmHg, and HCO3- 29 mEq/L	E: pH 7.48, PCO2 24 mmHg, and HCO3- 25 mEq/L
C

The boy is somnolent, lethargic, and appears to be grasping at his ears. This suggests salicylate toxicity. Salicylate toxicity can cause metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap due to the accumulation of salicylic acid in the blood. Therefore, the answer is: A

The boy is lethargic and responsive, and the most likely explanation for this is salicylate toxicity as he likely ingested the aspirin from the pill bottles. Salicylate toxicity causes respiratory alkalosis, which is characterized by an increased respiratory rate and a decreased PaCO2. The other answer choices reflect normal values or values seen in other conditions. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 63-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for an annual checkup. He is taking hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, simvastatin, metformin, and insulin. His blood pressure and lipid profile are stable. He has been complaining of a dry cough for several months, which has been worse over the past few weeks. Physical examination shows that his lungs are clear to auscultation. An abdominal examination shows mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies are significant for an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's cough?
Options: A: Pulmonary arterial hypertension	B: Heart failure	C: Drug toxicity	D: Benign prostatic hypertrophy	E: Renal failure
Answer: Drug toxicity is the most likely cause of the patient's cough because he is taking amlodipine, which can cause a dry cough as a side effect. Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker that is used to treat hypertension and angina. It can cause a dry cough in up to 10% of patients. The cough is usually mild and self-limited, but it can be persistent in some cases. Therefore, the answer is: C

The boy has vomited once in the emergency room, which suggests that he may have metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an elevated pH, a decreased PCO2, and an increased HCO3-. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 35-year-old man presents to the physician for evaluation of a 3-day history of bright red blood in his stool. The patient reports that he has also had diarrhea and abdominal pain. He also reports fatigue and weight loss over the past several months. Vital signs are normal and his physical examination is remarkable only for guaiac-positive stool. A colonoscopy reveals severe ulcerative colitis involving the sigmoid colon, the rectum, and the descending colon. The patient is started on mesalamine 4.8 g daily. Two months later, he remains symptomatic, and his colonoscopy shows no change. Which of the following medications is the next most appropriate medication to prescribe for this patient?
Options: A: Adalimumab	B: Budesonide	C: Octreotide	D: Olsalazine	E: Prednisone
Answer: A

Question: A 17-year-old man presents to his family physician for an evaluation about the size of his penis. He feels increasingly anxious during physical education (PE) class as he has noticed that the size of his penis is significantly smaller when compared to his peers. Based on the physical examination, he is Tanner stage 1. The weight and height are 60 kg (132 lb) and 175 cm (5 ft 9 in), respectively. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal; however, the patient has difficulty identifying coffee grounds by smell. Which of the following explains the pathophysiology underlying this patient’s disorder?
Options: A: Expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat	B: Isolated gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) deficiency	C: Sex-specific epigenetic imprinting	D: Leptin receptor mutation	E: Non-disjunction of sex chromosomes
B

Expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat is the most likely explanation for the pathophysiology underlying this patient's disorder. This patient has a small penis and difficulty identifying coffee grounds by smell. These findings suggest Kallmann syndrome, which is an X-linked disorder caused by the expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat in the KAL1 gene. This expansion leads to the loss of function of the KAL1 protein, which is necessary for the development of the olfactory bulbs and the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). GnRH is a hormone that stimulates the production of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), which are necessary for the development of puberty. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has difficulty identifying coffee grounds by smell, which suggests that he has Kallmann syndrome. Kallmann syndrome is caused by mutations in genes involved in the development of the hypothalamus and olfactory system. These mutations lead to a deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which is a hormone that stimulates the pituitary gland to produce luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). LH and FSH are necessary for the development of secondary sexual characteristics in males and females. Therefore, the answer is: B

The answer is: A

Expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat in the androgen receptor (AR) gene on the X chromosome is the pathophysiology underlying Fragile X syndrome. This expansion leads to hypermethylation of the gene and silencing of AR production. The resulting deficiency of AR leads to a reduction in androgen production, which results in the lack of Secondary sex characteristics and infertility in males. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has difficulty identifying coffee grounds by smell, which suggests Kallmann syndrome. Kallmann syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the development of the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. The hypothalamus produces gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which stimulates the pituitary gland to produce luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). LH and FSH are necessary for the development of the sex organs and the production of sex hormones. In Kallmann syndrome, the hypothalamus does not produce enough GnRH, which leads to a deficiency of LH and FSH. This results in delayed or absent puberty and infertility. The expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat in the X-linked KAL1 gene is the most common cause of Kallmann syndrome. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient is a 17-year-old boy with Tanner stage 1 and a decreased sense of smell. The combination of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (HH) and anosmia suggests a diagnosis of Kallmann syndrome. Kallmann syndrome is caused by mutations in genes that regulate the development of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis and the olfactory system. In this case, the patient likely has a mutation in the KAL1 gene, which encodes a protein involved in neuronal migration and axonal guidance. This mutation leads to the expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat in the KAL1 gene, which results in the production of a toxic protein that disrupts the development of the HPG axis and the olfactory system. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with the complaint of pain in his right toe for the past hour. The pain is so severe that it woke him up. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and binge drinks alcohol after work and on the weekends. He underwent an appendectomy when he was 14 years old. He is a long-distance truck driver. Neither of his parents had any significant medical history. His temperature is 37.7°C (100°F), blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and BMI is 25 kg/m2. On examination, his right first metatarsophalangeal joint is very tender, swollen, warm, and red in color. Range of motion cannot be assessed due to extreme tenderness.
Laboratory test
Complete blood count:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Leukocytes 16,000/mm3
Platelets 150,000/mm3
ESR 50 mm/hr
Synovial fluid is aspirated from the joint. The findings are:
Appearance Cloudy, dense yellow
WBC 30,000 cells/µL
Culture Negative
Needle-shaped birefringent crystals are observed in the joint aspirate. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s condition?
Options: A: Organic acids competing with urate for tubular secretion	B: Increased renal reabsorption of urate	C: Lysis of large numbers of cells	D: Deficiency of HGPRT	E: High-purine diet
A

The patient has a swollen, warm, and red right first metatarsophalangeal joint with extreme tenderness. Synovial fluid aspiration shows cloudy, dense yellow fluid with 30,000 cells/µL and needle-shaped birefringent crystals. These findings are consistent with gout. Gout is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. The crystals are formed when uric acid levels in the blood are high. Uric acid is a waste product that is produced when the body breaks down purines, which are found in some foods and are also produced by the body. Gout is treated with medications that lower uric acid levels in the blood. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has a history of smoking and alcohol abuse, which are risk factors for gout. He also has a swollen, tender, erythematous right first metatarsophalangeal joint. The joint aspirate shows elevated WBC count and needle-shaped birefringent crystals. These findings suggest gouty arthritis, which is a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in the joints. The crystals can be seen in the joint aspirate under a microscope. The most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition is increased renal reabsorption of urate. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has a swollen, warm, and red toe joint with severe pain. The joint fluid is cloudy, dense yellow, and contains needle-shaped birefringent crystals. This is consistent with a gout attack. Gout is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. The crystals are formed when uric acid, a waste product of purine metabolism, reaches high levels in the blood. High levels of uric acid can be caused by a number of factors, including a high-purine diet, decreased renal excretion of uric acid, and increased cell turnover. Therefore, the answer is: E

Needle-shaped birefringent crystals are observed in the joint aspirate. These are likely to be monosodium urate crystals, which are typically seen in gout. Gout is a disorder of purine metabolism that results in elevated levels of uric acid in the blood (hyperuricemia). Uric acid is a byproduct of purine catabolism. In gout, uric acid can form crystals that deposit in the joints, causing inflammation and pain. The most common joint affected by gout is the first metatarsophalangeal joint (the big toe). Therefore, the answer is: C

The synovial fluid aspirate from the patient's right first metatarsophalangeal joint shows cloudy, dense yellow appearance, 30,000 WBC/µL, and needle-shaped birefringent crystals. These findings are consistent with gouty arthritis, which is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. Gouty arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that is characterized by sudden, severe pain, swelling, and redness in the joints, most commonly the big toe. The most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition is increased renal reabsorption of urate. This can be caused by various factors, including dehydration, certain medications (such as diuretics and aspirin), and kidney disease. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 75-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of a productive cough and shortness of breath. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and respirations are 32/min. Crackles are heard over the right upper and the entire left lung fields. Sputum culture confirms infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae. Despite appropriate therapy, the patient dies. A photomicrograph of a section of the lung obtained during the autopsy is shown. Which of the following mediators is most likely responsible for the presence of the cell-type indicated by the arrow?
Options: A: Immunoglobulin E	B: Platelet activating factor	C: Interferon-gamma	D: Interleukin-10	E: Leukotriene D4
B

The photomicrograph shows a neutrophil, which is a type of white blood cell that is involved in the inflammatory response to infection. Neutrophils are recruited to the site of infection by various mediators, including interleukin-8 (IL-8). IL-8 is a potent neutrophil chemoattractant, which means that it attracts neutrophils to the site of infection. Therefore, the most likely mediator responsible for the presence of the cell-type indicated by the arrow is interleukin-8 (IL-8). Therefore, the answer is: C

The photomicrograph shows a neutrophil, which is a type of white blood cell that is recruited to sites of infection by the cytokine interleukin-8 (IL-8). IL-8 is produced by a variety of cells, including macrophages, neutrophils, and endothelial cells, in response to infection or tissue damage. It is a potent chemoattractant for neutrophils, and it also activates neutrophils and enhances their phagocytic and bactericidal activity. Therefore, the answer is: E

The cell-type indicated by the arrow is a neutrophil. Neutrophils are recruited to sites of infection by various mediators, including platelet activating factor (PAF). PAF is a potent inflammatory mediator that is released by activated platelets, macrophages, and neutrophils. It can cause increased vascular permeability, neutrophil chemotaxis, and degranulation. In this case, PAF is likely responsible for the presence of neutrophils in the lung tissue. Therefore, the answer is: B

The photomicrograph shows a section of lung tissue with a collection of neutrophils, which are a type of white blood cell that is recruited to the site of infection by various mediators. Platelet activating factor (PAF) is a potent mediator of inflammation that is released by activated platelets and other cells. It can cause leukocyte aggregation and degranulation, which can lead to the release of toxic oxygen radicals and other inflammatory mediators. PAF is also a potent bronchoconstrictor and can cause increased vascular permeability. Therefore, it is most likely responsible for the presence of the neutrophils in the lung tissue. Therefore, the answer is: B

The cell type indicated by the arrow is a mast cell. Mast cells are activated by immunoglobulin E (IgE), which binds to receptors on the surface of the mast cell. This activation leads to the release of a variety of mediators, including platelet activating factor (PAF), interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), interleukin-10 (IL-10), and leukotriene D4 (LTD4). Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A previously healthy 35-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a fever, persistent headache, nausea, and abdominal discomfort for 1 week. During this time, she has also noticed that her gums bleed while brushing her teeth. A month ago, she returned from a camping trip to Sri Lanka. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor and mild scleral icterus. There are a few scattered petechiae over the trunk and back. There is no lymphadenopathy. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 10,000/mm3
Platelet count 18,000/mm3
INR 1.0
Coomb's test negative
Fibrin split products negative
Serum
Urea 20 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 3.0 mg/dL
Direct 0.8 mg/dL
Alanine aminotransferase 20 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 16 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 900 U/L
Urine
Protein 1+
WBCs occasional
RBCs 50–60/hpf
Bacteria nil
A photograph of the peripheral blood smear is shown. Blood and urine cultures are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?"
Options: A: HELLP syndrome	B: Dengue hemorrhagic fever	C: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura	D: Hemolytic uremic syndrome	E: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
"
C

The patient has a fever, headache, nausea, hematuria, positive stool for occult blood, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia and liver dysfunction. These findings are classic for the hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). The peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes, which appear as fragmented red blood cells. HUS is a rare, life-threatening condition that affects the small blood vessels in the kidneys, causing them to become damaged and unable to filter waste products from the blood. This can lead to kidney failure, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. HUS is often associated with a recent infection with Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), a type of bacteria. In this case, the patient recently visited Sri Lanka, where STEC infections are common. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient is a primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation with fever, persistent headache, nausea, abdominal discomfort, bleeding gums, pallor, scleral icterus, petechiae, a positive test for occult blood in the stool, and laboratory findings of anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated serum bilirubin, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, and proteinuria. The peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes, which are red blood cells that have been fragmented due to mechanical damage. The most likely diagnosis is HELLP syndrome, which is a rare but serious complication of pregnancy characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets. The patient meets the diagnostic criteria for HELLP syndrome, which include:
Hemolysis: The patient has anemia and schistocytes on the peripheral blood smear.
Elevated liver enzymes: The patient has elevated serum alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase.
Low platelets: The patient has thrombocytopenia. HELLP syndrome can lead to serious complications, including liver failure, kidney failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has a fever, headache, nausea, abdominal discomfort, bleeding gums, pallor, scleral icterus, petechiae, a positive stool occult blood test, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. The peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. These findings are consistent with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). HUS is a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. It is often caused by Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) infection. The most likely diagnosis is HUS. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has a fever, headache, nausea, abdominal discomfort, bleeding gums, pallor, scleral icterus, petechiae, positive stool occult blood, low hemoglobin, low platelet count, increased INR, negative Coomb's test, negative fibrin split products, elevated urea and creatinine, elevated bilirubin, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, proteinuria, and hematuria. The peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. These findings are consistent with hemolytic uremic syndrome. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has a fever, persistent headache, nausea, abdominal discomfort, and bleeding gums. She has pallor, mild scleral icterus, and scattered petechiae. The laboratory studies show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. The peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. The urine shows proteinuria, occasional white blood cells, and 50-60 red blood cells per high power field. The positive Coomb's test and negative fibrin split products rule out autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, respectively. The most likely diagnosis is hemolytic uremic syndrome. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A researcher is interested in identifying the most effective treatment for uncomplicated urinary tract infections (UTI) in women between the ages of 18 and 50. Of 200 consecutive women who present to the emergency room for such a UTI, 50 are randomized to each of the following: nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days, cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, and cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days. The measured outcomes include progression to pyelonephritis, positive urine culture on day 7 after initiation of treatment, and likelihood of re-presenting to the emergency room for another UTI within 90 days. Which of the following best describes this type of study?
Options: A: Parallel study	B: Factorial design study	C: Non-crossover study	D: Between patient study	E: Cluster randomized trial
B

This is a parallel study. A parallel study is a type of clinical trial in which participants are randomly assigned to one of two or more treatment groups and followed over time to compare the effectiveness of the different treatments. In this study, the researcher is comparing the effectiveness of four different treatment regimens for uncomplicated urinary tract infections in women between the ages of 18 and 50 years. The measured outcomes include progression to pyelonephritis, positive urine culture on day 7 after initiation of treatment, and likelihood of re-presenting to the emergency room for another UTI within 90 days. Therefore, the answer is: A

A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with a history of exposure to a close friend who was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. She was told by her friend that she need to see a physician because she needs to be treated as well, even if she is not having symptoms yet. She currently denies any headaches, vision changes, nausea or vomiting, or neck stiffness. Her physical exam is within normal limits. Her vital signs are stable. She is prescribed rifampin for prophylaxis with specific instructions on when to follow up if symptoms develop. When asked about the possibility of pregnancy, she mentioned that she uses combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The physician suggested that her husband should use condoms for contraception as she requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the need for additional contraception?
Options: A: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens.	B: Rifampin inhibits CYP3A4, which metabolizes progestins.	C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.	D: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of estrogens.	E: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of progestins.
Answer: C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.

Parallel study is a type of clinical trial in which participants are randomly assigned to one of two or more different treatment groups and followed over time to compare the effects of the different treatments. In this study, the participants are randomly assigned to one of four different treatment groups: nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days, cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, and cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days. The outcomes are then compared between the groups to determine which treatment is most effective. Therefore, the answer is: A
The study is a parallel study because the participants are randomized to one of four different treatment groups and followed over time to compare the outcomes. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patients are randomly assigned to one of four treatments. The study is non-crossover because the patients receive only one treatment. The study is also between patient because the patients are randomized individually, not in groups. Therefore, the answer is: D

In this study, 200 women are randomized to one of four treatment groups: nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days, cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, or cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days. This is a between-patient study because each patient is assigned to only one treatment group, and the outcomes are measured individually for each patient. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 19-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department after collapsing during a cheerleading practice session. Her vitals taken by the emergency medical services (EMS) include blood pressure 88/55 mm Hg, pulse 55/min. She was given a liter of isotonic fluid while en route to the hospital. At the emergency department, she is alert and oriented and is noted to be anorexic. The patient fervently denies being underweight claiming that she is ‘a fatty’ and goes on to refuse any further intravenous fluid and later, even the hospital meals. Which of the following is the best option for long-term management of this patient’s condition?
Options: A: Cognitive-behavioral therapy	B: In-patient medical therapy	C: In-patient psychiatric therapy	D: Antidepressants	E: Appetite stimulants
A

In-patient psychiatric therapy is the best option for long-term management of this patient’s condition. This patient exhibits behaviors consistent with an eating disorder, specifically anorexia nervosa. Patients with anorexia nervosa have a distorted body image and an intense fear of gaining weight. They severely restrict their food intake and may engage in excessive exercise or purging behaviors. In-patient psychiatric therapy can provide a safe and structured environment for the patient to receive the necessary medical and psychological care. Therefore, the answer is: C

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a form of psychotherapy that helps people change their thinking patterns and behaviors. It has been shown to be effective in the treatment of eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa. CBT can help patients to challenge their negative thoughts about food and weight, develop healthier eating habits, and improve their body image. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has anorexia nervosa, an eating disorder characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight, a distorted body image, and severe restriction of food intake. The patient also fervently denies being underweight, claiming that she is ‘a fatty’, and refuses intravenous fluid and hospital meals. This suggests that the patient has a distorted body image and is in denial about her condition. The best option for long-term management of this patient’s condition is in-patient psychiatric therapy, as it addresses the underlying psychological issues that contribute to the eating disorder. Cognitive-behavioral therapy, antidepressants, and appetite stimulants are not as effective as in-patient psychiatric therapy in the long-term management of anorexia nervosa. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has anorexia nervosa, which is an eating disorder characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight, a distorted body image, and severe food restriction. The best option for long-term management of this patient's condition is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT is a type of psychotherapy that helps patients change their negative thoughts and behaviors about food and weight. It has been shown to be effective in treating anorexia nervosa and other eating disorders. Therefore, the answer is: A

The best option for long-term management of this patient’s condition is in-patient psychiatric therapy. This patient most likely suffers from anorexia nervosa because of her fervent denial of being underweight, claiming she is ‘a fatty,’ and refusing intravenous fluid, meals, and oral fluids. Long-term management of anorexia nervosa includes cognitive-behavioral therapy and in-patient psychiatric therapy to help the patient develop healthy eating habits and coping mechanisms. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after a motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious upon arrival and is found to have severe internal bleeding due to trauma. He is taken for emergency surgery and severely damaged tissues are removed. After surgery, the boy is taken into the PICU for recovery. Over the subsequent week, serial labs are drawn showing target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. He is started on a prophylactic regimen that is continued upon discharge. Which of the following is consistent with the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed in this case?
Options: A: 30S ribosome inhibitor	B: 50S ribosome inhibitor	C: Cell wall cross-linking inhibitor	D: DNA gyrase inhibitor	E: Folate metabolism inhibitor
C

The boy likely received a prophylactic regimen of a penicillin-type antibiotic, such as penicillin or amoxicillin. Penicillins act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis in bacteria by binding to the transpeptidase enzyme that cross-links the cell wall components. This results in the production of target cells, which are bacteria with abnormal cell walls. Therefore, the answer is: C

50S ribosome inhibitor is consistent with the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed in this case. Target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis are all signs of increased erythropoiesis. Erythropoiesis is the process by which red blood cells are produced. 50S ribosome inhibitors are drugs that inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome. This inhibition of protein synthesis can lead to an increase in erythropoiesis, which can result in the production of target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has severe trauma, and prophylactic antibiotic therapy is begun. Thrombocytosis and leukocytosis are consistent with the stress response and do not indicate development of infection. Thus, the most likely drug prescribed is a prophylactic antibiotic. Prophylactic antibiotics in this case are typically broad-spectrum and are designed to prevent infection. Penicillin is an antibiotic that inhibits synthesis of the bacterial cell wall. Penicillin will target bacteria that are undergoing active multiplication. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis, which are all signs of ineffective erythropoiesis. Ineffective erythropoiesis occurs when the bone marrow produces red blood cells that are not able to mature properly. This can be caused by a variety of factors, including infection, inflammation, and certain drugs. The drug that is most likely to cause ineffective erythropoiesis is a folate metabolism inhibitor. Folate is an essential nutrient that is required for the synthesis of DNA and RNA. Folate metabolism inhibitors block the synthesis of folate, which can lead to the production of abnormal red blood cells. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient has severe internal bleeding due to trauma and underwent surgery to remove severely damaged tissues. After surgery, he developed target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. These findings are consistent with post-splenectomy syndrome, which is a condition that can occur after the removal of the spleen. The spleen plays an important role in the removal of old or damaged red blood cells, platelets, and white blood cells from the bloodstream. After splenectomy, these cells can accumulate in the bloodstream, leading to the development of target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. Prophylactic antibiotics are typically prescribed to prevent infection in patients with post-splenectomy syndrome. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening involuntary movements of both arms for the past 7 months. He reports that certain daily activities have become more difficult to perform. His father had a similar condition that was treated with medications. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a low-amplitude tremor bilaterally when the arms are outstretched that worsens when reaching out to grab a pen. Muscle strength and tone is normal bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. On mental status examination, his mood is good. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Deep brain stimulation	B: Thalamotomy	C: Levodopa and carbidopa therapy	D: Clonazepam therapy	E: Propranolol therapy
E

Levodopa and carbidopa therapy is the most appropriate next step in management because the patient has a history of worsening involuntary movements of both arms, a family history of a similar condition, and a low-amplitude tremor that worsens with reaching. These findings suggest Parkinson's disease, which is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by a loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra. Levodopa is a dopamine precursor that can be converted to dopamine in the brain, and carbidopa is a decarboxylase inhibitor that prevents the peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine. Therefore, the answer is: C

Levodopa and carbidopa therapy is the most appropriate next step in management because this combination is the first-line treatment for Parkinson's disease. Levodopa is a dopamine precursor that is converted to dopamine in the brain. Carbidopa is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor that prevents the breakdown of levodopa in the periphery, allowing more levodopa to reach the brain. This combination therapy is effective in reducing the symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has worsening involuntary movements of both arms for the past 7 months. Certain daily activities have become more difficult to perform. Examination shows a low-amplitude tremor bilaterally when the arms are outstretched that worsens when reaching out to grab a pen. The patient's father had a similar condition that was treated with medications. These findings suggest essential tremor. Levodopa and carbidopa therapy is the treatment of choice for essential tremor. Therefore, the answer is: C

Levodopa and carbidopa therapy is the most appropriate next step in management. Levodopa is a precursor of dopamine, which is a neurotransmitter that is deficient in Parkinson's disease. Carbidopa is an inhibitor of peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa, which allows more levodopa to reach the brain and reduce the risk of side effects. Therefore, the answer is: C

C: Levodopa and carbidopa therapy is the most appropriate next step in management. Levodopa is a dopamine precursor that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is converted to dopamine in the brain. Carbidopa is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of levodopa to dopamine outside the brain, thereby reducing the risk of side effects such as nausea and vomiting. Levodopa and carbidopa therapy is the first-line treatment for Parkinson's disease. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a physician by his mother for evaluation of generalized weakness, increased urination, and increased thirst. The mother mentions that her boy is always tired, and seems to be getting worse. He prefers watching television rather than going out and playing with other kids. Furthermore, he has had frequent episodes of constipation since birth. Except for frequent cravings for salty foods, the boy eats a regular diet. The patient was delivered healthy and is fully immunized. The medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He has no siblings. His father is a banker and his mother is a librarian. The pulse is 90/min, the blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 15/min. He is in the bottom 10th percentile for height and weight according to his age. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. He recently had a urinalysis that showed elevated urinary calcium excretion.
Additional lab testing results are as follows:
Serum electrolytes
Sodium 135 mEq/L
Potassium 3.2 mEq/L
Chloride 95 mEq/L
Plasma renin activity 10 ng/mL/hr (normal, 0.5–3.3 ng/mL/hr)
Plasma aldosterone concentration 20 ng/dL (normal, 2–9 ng/dL)
What is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Renal artery stenosis	B: Primary hyperaldosteronism	C: Bartter's syndrome	D: Pheochromocytoma	E: Gitelman's syndrome
C

The patient has generalized weakness, increased urination, increased thirst, constipation, and elevated urinary calcium excretion. He has hyponatremia, hypokalemia, elevated plasma renin activity, and elevated plasma aldosterone concentration. Bartter's syndrome is a rare, inherited disorder characterized by salt loss due to impaired sodium and chloride reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This leads to hypochloremic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hyperreninemia, and hyperaldosteronism. The most common cause of Bartter's syndrome is mutations in the NKCC2 gene, which encodes a transporter responsible for sodium and chloride reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Therefore, the answer is: C

The increased urinary calcium excretion combined with the elevated plasma renin activity and elevated plasma aldosterone concentration suggest Bartter's syndrome, a rare kidney disorder that causes the kidneys to lose too much salt and water. This can lead to dehydration, weakness, and increased thirst. Children with Bartter's syndrome may also have low blood pressure, muscle weakness, and constipation. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has generalized weakness, increased urination, increased thirst, fatigue, constipation, and cravings for salty foods. He has elevated urinary calcium excretion, low potassium, high plasma renin activity, and high plasma aldosterone concentration. These findings are consistent with Bartter's syndrome, a rare inherited disorder of the kidney tubules that leads to excessive loss of salt and water. The most likely diagnosis is Bartter's syndrome. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has generalized weakness, increased urination, increased thirst, constipation, and a history of craving salty foods. He has elevated urinary calcium excretion, elevated plasma renin activity, and elevated plasma aldosterone concentration. These findings suggest Bartter's syndrome, which is a rare kidney disorder that leads to the loss of sodium, potassium, and chloride in the urine. This can lead to dehydration, weakness, and fatigue. Patients with Bartter's syndrome may also have increased urination, increased thirst, and constipation. They may also crave salty foods because the body is trying to replace the sodium that is being lost in the urine. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has generalized weakness, increased urination, and increased thirst. He is in the bottom 10th percentile for height and weight according to his age and has frequent episodes of constipation since birth. His plasma renin activity is elevated and his plasma aldosterone concentration is elevated. The most likely diagnosis is Bartter's syndrome, which is a rare inherited disorder characterized by low blood potassium levels, high blood pressure, and increased urination. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department for clear vaginal discharge that started roughly 26 hours ago. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her first child was born at term by vaginal delivery. She has no history of any serious illnesses. She does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Current medications include vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Speculum examination demonstrates clear fluid at the cervical os. The fetal heart rate is reactive at 160/min with no decelerations. Tocometry shows uterine contractions. Nitrazine testing is positive. She is started on indomethacin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Administer ampicillin and perform amnioinfusion	B: Administer ampicillin and progesterone	C: Administer ampicillin and test amniotic fluid for fetal lung maturity	D: Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with cesarean section	E: Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with induction of labor
D

The patient is at 32 weeks' gestation and has premature rupture of membranes (PROM). The next step is to administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with induction of labor. Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that helps to mature the fetal lungs. Ampicillin is an antibiotic that is used to prevent infection. Induction of labor is the process of starting labor artificially. Therefore, the answer is: E

This patient is 32 weeks' gestation and has premature rupture of membranes (PROM). The most appropriate next step in management is to administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with induction of labor. Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that helps to mature the fetal lungs. Ampicillin is an antibiotic that helps to prevent infection. Induction of labor is done to deliver the baby before infection can occur. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient is at 32 weeks' gestation and has clear vaginal discharge, a positive Nitrazine test, and uterine contractions. This suggests preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). The next step is to administer betamethasone and ampicillin to promote fetal lung maturity and prevent infection. Induction of labor is not appropriate at this time because the fetus is not yet mature. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient is at 32 weeks' gestation and has clear vaginal discharge. She is started on indomethacin to stop uterine contractions. The next step in management is to administer betamethasone and ampicillin and proceed with induction of labor. Betamethasone is given to accelerate fetal lung maturity, and ampicillin is given to prevent Group B streptococcal infection. Induction of labor is done to deliver the baby before the infection progresses. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient is at 32 weeks' gestation with ruptured membranes. The next step is to administer betamethasone and ampicillin and proceed with induction of labor. Betamethasone is given to accelerate fetal lung maturity, and ampicillin is given to prevent maternal and neonatal infection. Induction of labor is performed to deliver the baby before infection can develop. Therefore, the answer is: E

Question: A 72-year-old man develops reduced urine output and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.9 mg/dL three days after being hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. On admission, a complete blood count showed a hemoglobin concentration of 15.5 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 14,000/mm3. Urinalysis showed 2+ proteinuria, and serum studies showed a blood glucose of 145 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.2 mg/dL. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed the diagnosis. Therapy with intravenous ketoprofen, piperacillin, and tazobactam was begun, and the patient was placed on bowel rest. He has a history of hypertension, chronic constipation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin, metoprolol, and losartan. Today, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft on physical examination, and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current renal findings?
Options: A: Gastrointestinal blood loss	B: Adverse drug reaction	C: Dehydration	D: Contrast administration	E: Chronic hypertension
"
D

The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI), which is defined as an abrupt decrease in kidney function. The most likely cause of AKI in this patient is dehydration, which can occur due to bowel rest and decreased oral intake. Dehydration can lead to a decrease in blood volume and a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, which can result in an increase in serum creatinine concentration and a decrease in urine output. Therefore, the answer is: C

The most likely cause of this patient's current renal findings is dehydration. He has a history of chronic constipation and type 2 diabetes mellitus, which may have contributed to his dehydration. He has been hospitalized for 3 days and has been on bowel rest, which may have further contributed to his dehydration. He may also have had gastrointestinal blood loss, which can also lead to dehydration. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 54-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of low back pain. He experienced a near-syncopal episode last night and was found to be febrile. The pain is worse with recumbency and improved with walking. The only relief is when he is standing or walking for at least 1 hour. He denies any bowel or bladder dysfunction. His temperature today is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Examination reveals absence of a straight leg raise on the right and moderate tenderness over the spinous processes of L3–L5. Reflexes and sensation are normal. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
Options: A: Anti-tuberculous drugs	B: Antibiotics	C: Needle aspiration	D: Surgical drainage	E: Spinal decompression
Answer: The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a large abscess in the right iliacus muscle. The abscess is likely the source of the patient's fever and back pain. The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient is surgical drainage of the abscess. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has a history of hypertension, chronic constipation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was hospitalized for acute diverticulitis and is now experiencing reduced urine output and an elevated serum creatinine concentration. The patient is also receiving piperacillin and tazobactam, which can cause nephrotoxicity. The most likely cause of the patient's current renal findings is piperacillin and tazobactam, which can cause nephrotoxicity. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 2-month-old boy presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress. He has been experiencing difficulty breathing for the past 2 days, and his parents report that he has been coughing up green sputum. He has a history of prematurity and bronchopulmonary dysplasia. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 75/40 mm Hg. On examination, he is in respiratory distress with subcostal retractions and wheezing throughout the lungs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's respiratory distress?
Options: A: Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis	B: Bronchiolitis	C: Cystic fibrosis	D: Pertussis	E: Viral pneumonia
Answer: Bronchiolitis is a common lower respiratory tract infection that affects infants and young children. It is caused by a variety of viruses, including respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), parainfluenza virus, and adenovirus. Symptoms of bronchiolitis include cough, wheezing, and difficulty breathing. In severe cases, bronchiolitis can lead to respiratory failure. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent diarrhea and fatigue for 1 month. She has had up to 12 watery stools per day. Sometimes she awakens at night because she has to defecate. She has abdominal bloating and cramps. She has had a 2-kg weight loss in the past month. She returned from a trip to Costa Rica 7 weeks ago. She has a history of bronchial asthma and bulimia nervosa. She works as a nurse. She does not smoke and drinks 1–2 beers on the weekend. Current medications include fish oil, a multivitamin, and a salbutamol inhaler. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Abdominal and rectal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 46%
Leukocyte Count 6,500/mm3
Platelet Count 220,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
K+ 3.2 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
HCO3- 33 mEq/L
Mg2+ 3.3 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL
Abdominal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy shows dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots. Biopsies of colonic mucosa are obtained and sent for pathological evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?"
Options: A: Celiac disease	B: Carcinoid tumor	C: VIPoma	D: Irritable bowel syndrome	E: Medication abuse
E

The patient has dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots on colonoscopy. Biopsies of colonic mucosa show pseudomembranous colitis, which is a condition caused by an overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile (formerly known as Clostridium difficile) in the colon. Clostridioides difficile is a bacterium that can cause diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. It is often associated with antibiotic use. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma and bulimia nervosa, both of which are risk factors for Clostridioides difficile infection. Therefore, the answer is: A

The most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms is VIPoma because she has a history of watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, and she has recently traveled to an endemic area (Costa Rica). The colonoscopy shows dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots, which is characteristic of VIPoma. Biopsies of colonic mucosa have been obtained and sent for pathological evaluation, which will confirm the diagnosis. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has a history of travel to an area where tropical sprue is endemic. She has persistent diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal bloating and cramps. Colonoscopy shows dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots. The most likely underlying cause is tropical sprue, which is a malabsorption disorder caused by bacterial or protozoal overgrowth in the small intestine. The dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots is a characteristic finding of tropical sprue. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has diarrhea, abdominal bloating and cramps, weight loss, and dark colored mucosa with interspersed white spots on colonoscopy. These findings suggest a carcinoid tumor, which is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in the gastrointestinal tract. Carcinoid tumors can produce various hormones, including serotonin, which can cause diarrhea and other symptoms. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has a history of travel to Costa Rica, where there is a high prevalence of Giardia lamblia. She has persistent diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and cramps. Colonoscopy shows dark-colored mucosa with interspersed white spots, which is characteristic of Giardia lamblia infection. Therefore, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms is Giardia lamblia infection. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of sore mouth. He says that swallowing is not painful. He has had asthma for more than 20 years. His only medication is a high-dose combination salmeterol/fluticasone inhaler. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/65 mm Hg. A photograph of his oral mucosa is shown. Indirect mirror examination of the posterior oropharynx, larynx, and hypopharynx shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Azithromycin	B: Fluconazole	C: Isotretinoin	D: Nystatin	E: Penicillin V
D

The photograph shows a hairy tongue. This is a benign condition characterized by an overgrowth of filiform papillae on the tongue. The papillae can trap food particles and bacteria, which can lead to a bad taste in the mouth and halitosis. Treatment is not typically necessary, but antifungal medications, such as nystatin, can be used to treat any underlying fungal infection. Therefore, the answer is: D

The most appropriate next step in management is fluconazole because the patient has pseudomembranous candidiasis, which is a fungal infection of the oral mucosa. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication that is effective in treating candidiasis. Therefore, the answer is: B

The photograph shows white, curd-like plaques on the oral mucosa. The patient has been using a high-dose combination salmeterol/fluticasone inhaler, which is a risk factor for oral candidiasis. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has a white, thin membrane spread on the dorsal tongue. He also has asthma and is on high-dose salmeterol/fluticasone inhaler. Nystatin is a topical antifungal agent that is active against Candida species. Salmeterol/fluticasone inhalers can cause oral candidiasis. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has white plaques on the oral mucosa. He has no dysphagia. He is taking a high-dose combination salmeterol/fluticasone inhaler, which can suppress the immune system and increase the risk of oral candidiasis. The most appropriate next step is to treat with an antifungal agent such as nystatin or fluconazole. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1a) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular hypoxia. In normoxia, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of HIF-1a, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by VHL is inhibited under hypoxic conditions, allowing HIF-1a to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to angiogenesis. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment?
Options: A: A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.	B: A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.	C: A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.	D: A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.	E: A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.
E

A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.

Western blotting is a technique used to detect specific proteins in a sample. In this experiment, the researcher wants to detect HIF-1a in RCC cells under normoxic conditions. Since RCC can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia, it is likely that HIF-1a will be present in higher levels in RCC cells under normoxic conditions compared to normoxic control cells. Therefore, a Western blot would show increased HIF-1a protein levels in RCC cells compared to a normoxic control.

Northern blotting and Southern blotting are techniques used to detect RNA and DNA, respectively. They are not appropriate techniques for detecting proteins.

A Western blot will show increased HIF-1a compared to a normoxic control. Western blot is a technique used to detect specific proteins in a sample. In this experiment, the researcher wants to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions. Since RCC can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia, HIF-1a will accumulate in RCC cells compared to normoxic control cells. Therefore, a Western blot will show increased HIF-1a in RCC cells compared to a normoxic control cell. Therefore, the answer is: E

A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control. Western blotting is a technique used to detect specific proteins in a sample. In this experiment, the researcher wants to detect HIF-1α in RCC cells under normoxic conditions. Therefore, a Western blot would be the most appropriate technique to use. A Northern blot is used to detect RNA molecules, a Southern blot is used to detect DNA molecules, and arteriography is used to visualize blood vessels. Therefore, the answer is: E

A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control. Western blotting is a technique used to detect specific proteins in a sample. In this case, the researcher wants to detect HIF-1α in RCC under normoxic conditions. The Western blot will show increased HIF-1α in the RCC cells compared to the normoxic control cells because HIF-1α is stabilized under normoxic conditions in RCC due to the inhibition of HIF-1α hydroxylation by VHL protein. Therefore, the answer is: E

In RCC, HIF-1a hydroxylation is inhibited even in the absence of hypoxia, leading to increased HIF-1a levels. A Western blot can be used to detect protein levels, including HIF-1a. Therefore, a Western blot will show increased HIF-1a compared to a normoxic control. Therefore, the answer is: E

Question: A previously healthy 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, he attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomoyopathy	B: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation	C: Brugada syndrome	D: Ventricular tachycardia	E: Sick sinus syndrome
B

The ECG shows a regular heart rate of 155 bpm. The P waves are absent, indicating that the atria are not generating impulses. Question: A 45-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue, lethargy, and epigastric pain after eating. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. Her caretakers state that the patient’s gait suddenly became ataxic, and she became less responsive than her normal non-verbal baseline. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 125/68 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an unremarkable HEENT exam with normal facial features and no signs of airway compromise. Neurological exam is remarkable for new onset spasticity. The patient has 3+ reflexes and a positive Babinski sign. Musculoskeletal exam is only notable for symmetric swelling and deformities of the patient’s hands bilaterally. Additionally, there is a "clunk" when posterior force is applied to the head while anterior force is applied to the cervical spine. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor that predisposed this patient to this condition?
Options: A: Cerebral palsy	B: Diabetes mellitus	C: Down syndrome	D: Hypertension	E: Rheumatoid arthritis
E

The patient has a change in her behavior, ataxia, decreased responsiveness, new onset spasticity, and a positive Babinski sign. These findings suggest a neurological disorder. Therefore, the answer is: B

The most likely risk factor that predisposed this patient to this condition is Down syndrome. Down syndrome is a genetic disorder that is associated with an increased risk of atlantoaxial instability, or instability of the joint between the first and second cervical vertebrae. This instability can lead to compression of the spinal cord and symptoms such as ataxia, spasticity, and Babinski sign. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has a history of mental retardation, which is a risk factor for atlantoaxial instability (AAI). AAI is a condition in which the atlantoaxial joint, which connects the first and second cervical vertebrae, is unstable. This can lead to spinal cord compression and neurological symptoms, such as gait ataxia, spasticity, and Babinski sign. Rheumatoid arthritis is also a risk factor for AAI, but the patient does not have a history of this condition. Therefore, the answer is: A

Individuals with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing atlantoaxial instability (AAI), a condition in which the first and second cervical vertebrae (C1 and C2) are unstable. This instability can lead to spinal cord compression and neurological deficits, such as ataxia and spasticity. The presence of a "clunk" when posterior force is applied to the head while anterior force is applied to the cervical spine is a classic sign of AAI. Therefore, the answer is: C

The most likely risk factor that predisposed this patient to this condition is rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that can affect the joints, skin, lungs, heart, and blood vessels. It can also cause inflammation of the synovium, the lining of the joints. This inflammation can lead to pain, swelling, and stiffness in the joints. In some cases, rheumatoid arthritis can also cause inflammation of the spinal cord, which can lead to ataxia, or difficulty with coordination. Therefore, the answer is: E

Question: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of headache, fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past 4 days. Question: An investigator is studying the frequency of polycythemia in a population of a remote, mountainous region. A representative sample of 100 men shows a normal distribution of hemoglobin concentration with a mean concentration of 17 g/dL and a standard error of 0.1 g/dL. Which of the following best represents the probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL?

The probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL can be calculated using the standard normal distribution. The z-score for a hemoglobin concentration of 18 g/dL is (18 - 17) / 0.1 = 1. The probability that a subject will have a z-score greater than 1 is 1 - 0.8413 = 0.1587. Therefore, the probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL is 15.87%. Therefore, the answer is: B

The z-score for a hemoglobin concentration of 18 g/dL is (18 - 17) / 0.1 = 10. Therefore, the answer is: E

The z-score for a hemoglobin concentration of 18 g/dL is (18 g/dL - 17 g/dL) / 0.1 g/dL = 1. The probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL is the same as the probability that a z-score is greater than 1. Question: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension, obesity, and alcoholic cirrhosis is seen in clinic for follow-up. He feels well and currently drinks 5 glasses of wine each night. Question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of progressively worsening swelling around the eyes. He has no history of major medical illness. He had a sore throat and cough 2 weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows moderate periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. A kidney biopsy specimen shows effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy. Which of the following is most likely to be found on urinalysis?
Options: A: Hyaline casts and immunoglobulins	B: Red blood cell casts and acanthocytes	C: Fatty casts and albumin	D: White blood cell casts and eosinophils	E: Granular casts and tubular epithelial cells
C

A 24-year-old woman presents to a physician with a history of exposure to a close friend who was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. She was told by her friend that she need to see a physician because she needs to be treated as well, even if she is not having symptoms yet. C: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of progestins.	D: Rifampin directly interferes with intestinal absorption of estrogens. The patient has periorbital edema, pitting edema of the lower extremities, and effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy. These findings are consistent with nephrotic syndrome. Question: A 24-year-old woman gravida 2, para 1 at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her earlier pregnancy was uncomplicated. The patient is Rh-positive, so the next step in management is Rh antibody testing to determine her Rh status. If the patient is Rh-negative, she will need to receive Rh immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) to prevent Rh sensitization. Therefore, the answer is: C

Rh sensitization can lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), which is a serious condition that can cause anemia, jaundice, and other health problems in the baby. Rh antibody testing is the most appropriate next step in management because the patient is Rh positive and her baby is likely Rh negative. Question: In a study, 2 groups are placed on different statin medications, statin A and statin B. Baseline LDL levels are drawn for each group and are subsequently measured every 3 months for 1 year. The symptoms are real and can be very distressing, but they are not caused by any organic disease. They may also have a history of mental health problems, such as depression or anxiety. The most likely diagnosis for this patient is somatization disorder. She has a history of multiple visits to the emergency room with similar symptoms, and there is no evidence of any underlying medical condition. Therefore, the answer is: C

Illness anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious illness. People with this disorder may have physical symptoms that they believe are signs of a serious illness, even though there is no medical evidence to support this belief. They may also avoid situations or activities that they believe could make them sick. The diagnosis of illness anxiety disorder is based on the patient's history and physical examination. Laboratory studies are not typically needed. Treatment typically involves psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, and medication, such as antidepressants. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 3 days. During this period, he has had severe itching and was not able to sleep well. Question: A 56-year-old man recently diagnosed with cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use presents to the clinic for a follow up evaluation. Endoscopic sclerotherapy is the next best step to prevent bleeding. Esophageal varices are dilated veins in the esophagus that can bleed if they rupture. Question: A 52-year-old fisherman presents to the clinic for an evaluation of a pigmented lesion on his neck. Question: A 23-year-old man presents to the office for a circular, itchy rash over the abdomen that has been slowly getting worse for the past 2 weeks. Question: A 23-year-old woman presents to her psychiatrist concerned about her mood. She has felt tired and unwilling to engage in any activities lately. Question: A 38-year-old G4P3 presents to her obstetrician’s office for her 20-week anatomy ultrasound. She reports that she feels well and has not experienced any contractions or vaginal bleeding. Question: A 69-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for trouble sleeping. The patient states that he recently retired from working the day shift at a cemetery. The patient has a history of working the day shift at a cemetery and now that he is retired, he is unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening. This is also consistent with advanced sleep phase disorder, as people with this disorder often have good quality sleep, but they are unable to stay awake during the desired times. Therefore, the answer is: C

The most likely diagnosis is advanced sleep phase disorder. This is a condition in which a person has a sleep-wake cycle that is shifted earlier than normal. This means that the person falls asleep early in the evening and wakes up early in the morning. When he retired, he tried to adjust his sleep schedule to be more in line with his wife's, but he found that he was unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening. He is now unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening and feels rested when he awakes, which is consistent with advanced sleep phase disorder.
