The correct answer is: A: Rifampin alters normal gastrointestinal flora, which leads to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens.

The CD8 protein is expressed on the surface of cytotoxic T cells. Cytotoxic T cells are responsible for killing infected cells. The primary function of the protein that binds to CD8 is to bind exogenous peptides that have been transported by the TAP channel. This protein is called the T cell receptor (TCR). The TCR binds to peptides presented on MHC class I molecules on the surface of infected cells. This binding event triggers the activation of the cytotoxic T cell, leading to the killing of the infected cell. Therefore, the answer is: E

The primary function of the protein that was most likely identified is to bind exogenous peptides that have been transported by the TAP channel. This protein is the major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC I) protein, which is expressed on the surface of all nucleated cells. MHC I molecules bind exogenous peptides that are derived from foreign proteins, such as those from viruses or bacteria. These peptides are transported into the endoplasmic reticulum by the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) channel. Once bound to MHC I molecules, the peptides are transported to the cell surface, where they can be recognized by CD8+ cytotoxic T cells. Therefore, the answer is: E

Question: A group of investigators is studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. Which of the following best describes this study design?
Options: A: Case-control study	B: Cross-sectional study	C: Case series	D: Retrospective cohort study	E: Randomized controlled trial
A

Case-control study is a retrospective epidemiological study design in which two groups of people are compared: a group of people with an outcome (e.g., interstitial lung disease) and a group of people without the outcome (e.g., people without interstitial lung disease). The investigators then compare the exposure to the fire retardant chemical between the two groups to determine whether there is an association between exposure and the outcome. Therefore, the answer is: A

The investigators are studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. This is a case-control study because the investigators are comparing the exposure to the chemical in people with interstitial lung disease to the exposure in people without the disease. Therefore, the answer is: A

A case-control study is a type of observational study in which people with a certain condition or outcome (cases) are compared with people who do not have the condition or outcome (controls). The researchers look back in time to compare the exposures of the two groups to see if there is an association between exposure to a certain factor and the development of the condition or outcome. In this case, the researchers are comparing people with interstitial lung disease to people without the disease to see if there is an association between exposure to the fire retardant chemical and the development of interstitial lung disease. Therefore, the answer is: A

The study design best described as a case-control study. In a case-control study, individuals with a disease (cases) are compared with individuals without the disease (controls) to determine whether there is an association between exposure to a particular factor and the development of the disease. In this study, the cases are people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease, and the controls are people who have not been diagnosed with the disease. The investigators will compare the exposure to the fire retardant chemical between the cases and controls to determine whether there is an association between exposure to the chemical and the development of interstitial lung disease. Therefore, the answer is: A

The study design is a case-control study because the investigators are comparing a group of people with a disease (cases) to a group of people without the disease (controls) to determine whether there is an association between exposure to a particular factor (fire retardant chemical) and the development of the disease. The investigators are using hospital records to identify cases and controls, and they are using surveys and home visits to assess exposure to the chemical. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus; she has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye, but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Central retinal vein occlusion	B: Retinal detachment	C: Central retinal artery occlusion	D: Acute angle-closure glaucoma	E: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy
C

Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. This is consistent with a central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). CRAO is a sudden loss of blood flow to the retina due to blockage of the central retinal artery. This can occur due to a blood clot, an embolism, or a narrowing of the artery. The most common cause of CRAO is atherosclerosis. The symptoms of CRAO include sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye. The vision loss is usually severe, and the eye may be completely blind. Treatment for CRAO includes lowering intraocular pressure, improving perfusion pressure, and dissolving the clot. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye, with a pale, white retina and a bright red area within the macula on fundoscopic examination. This is most likely due to a central retinal artery occlusion. Central retinal artery occlusion is a sudden loss of vision due to a blockage of the central retinal artery, which supplies blood to the retina. The most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion is atherosclerosis, which can lead to the formation of a blood clot that blocks the artery. Other risk factors include hypertension, diabetes, and smoking. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is: C

The patient has sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye, with a pale, white retina and a bright red area within the macula on fundoscopic examination. This is consistent with central retinal artery occlusion. Central retinal artery occlusion is an ophthalmological emergency that occurs when the central retinal artery, which supplies blood to the retina, is blocked. This can lead to sudden, painless loss of vision in the affected eye. The retina appears pale and white on fundoscopic examination, with a cherry-red spot in the macula. Therefore, the answer is: C

The most likely diagnosis is central retinal artery occlusion. This is a sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye that is caused by a blockage of the central retinal artery, which supplies blood to the retina. The blockage can be caused by a blood clot, a piece of plaque from an atherosclerotic artery, or an embolus from the heart. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, all of which are risk factors for central retinal artery occlusion. The sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye, the absence of direct pupillary reflex in the right eye, and the pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula on fundoscopic examination are all consistent with central retinal artery occlusion. Therefore, the answer is: C

The woman has sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye with a pale, white retina and a bright red area within the macula. This is consistent with central retinal artery occlusion, which is a blockage of the main artery that supplies blood to the retina. This can lead to loss of vision in the affected eye. The other options are less likely because they do not explain the sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: Three days after admission to the intensive care unit for septic shock and bacteremia from a urinary tract infection, a 34-year-old woman has persistent hypotension. Her blood cultures are positive for Escherichia coli, for which she has been receiving appropriate antibiotics since admission. She has no history of any serious illness. She does not use illicit drugs. Current medications include norepinephrine, ceftriaxone, and acetaminophen. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate is 96/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral tenderness bilaterally. Examination of the thyroid gland shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
  Hospital day 1 Hospital day 3
Leukocyte count 18,500/mm3 10,300/mm3
Hemoglobin 14.1 mg/dL 13.4 mg/dL
Serum
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL 0.9 mg/dL
Fasting glucose 95 mg/dL 100 mg/dL
TSH   1.8 µU/mL
T3, free   0.1 ng/dL
T4, free   0.9 ng/dL
Repeat blood cultures are negative. A chest X-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Options: A: Bromocriptine	B: Levothyroxine	C: Removing toxic drugs	D: Thiamine therapy	E: Treating the underlying illness
E

The patient has persistent hypotension despite appropriate antibiotic therapy. She has costovertebral tenderness bilaterally, which is a sign of adrenal insufficiency. She also has low serum cortisol levels and an increased ACTH level. The most appropriate treatment is to treat the underlying illness, which is adrenal insufficiency. Therefore, the answer is: E

This patient has persistent hypotension despite appropriate antibiotic therapy for septic shock and bacteremia. The patient has costovertebral tenderness bilaterally and laboratory studies show hyponatremia, hypoalbuminemia, and elevated BUN and creatinine, consistent with Addison's disease. The patient does not have fever, tachycardia, or hypotension, which are not typically seen with Addison's disease. TSH is normal, making hypopituitarism unlikely. The correct approach in this case is to remove toxic drugs. Norepinephrine can cause hypotension in patients with adrenal insufficiency and may be contributing to the patient's hypotension. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has a high leukocyte count and serum creatinine, which indicate an ongoing infection or inflammation. She is also hypotensive and has a low TSH, T3, and T4 levels, which suggest thyroid insufficiency. The most appropriate treatment is treating the underlying illness (the infection) because the symptoms are due to septic shock from a urinary tract infection. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient has persistent hypotension despite appropriate antibiotics for Escherichia coli bacteremia. She has costovertebral tenderness bilaterally, suggesting pyelonephritis. Her thyroid function tests show low free T3 and T4 levels, and a normal TSH level, suggesting central hypothyroidism. The most appropriate treatment is levothyroxine to treat the hypothyroidism. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has hyperthyroidism, as evidenced by the elevated TSH, low free T3 and free T4 levels. The most appropriate treatment is removing toxic drugs. The patient is receiving acetaminophen, which can cause hepatotoxicity in high doses and can also interfere with thyroid hormone metabolism. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 41-year-old G3P1 woman presents with a sudden onset throbbing headache, tinnitus, nausea, and left-sided weakness. Patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications.  Her last two pregnancies ended with spontaneous abortions before the 10th week of gestation. No significant family history. Her vital signs include: blood pressure 130/90 mm Hg, pulse 58/min, respiratory rate 11/min, and temperature 36.8℃ (98.2℉). GCS is 14/15. Physical examination shows 3+ deep tendon reflexes and increased muscle tone in the left upper and lower extremities. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Platelet count 230,000/mm3
Fibrinogen 3.5 g/L
Activated partial thromboplastin time  70 s
Thrombin time 34 s
 A non-contrast CT of the head is performed and shown in the picture. Which of the following would be the next best diagnostic step in this patient?
Options: A: Mixing study	B: INR	C: D-dimer	D: Ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation test	E: Clot retraction study
A

Mixing study is a laboratory test that is used to evaluate the function of the coagulation factors in the blood. It is performed by mixing the patient's plasma with normal plasma and then testing the clotting time. A mixing study can help to identify deficiencies of specific coagulation factors. In this patient, the mixing study would be the next best diagnostic step because it would help to identify the specific coagulation factor deficiency that is causing the patient's bleeding. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has a noncontrast head CT scan showing a large right-sided intraparenchymal hemorrhage. A mixing study would be the next best diagnostic step in this patient. A mixing study is a laboratory test that is used to evaluate the function of platelets. It is performed by mixing the patient's blood with normal plasma and then observing the clotting time. A prolonged clotting time in the mixing study indicates that the patient's platelets are not functioning properly. This could be due to a number of factors, including a deficiency of clotting factors, an inhibitor of platelet function, or a platelet disorder. Therefore, the answer is: A

A mixing study is a laboratory test that is used to evaluate the function of platelets. The test is performed by mixing the patient's blood with normal donor plasma and then observing the ability of the platelets to aggregate. The next best diagnostic step in this patient is to perform a mixing study to assess platelet function. The patient has a history of spontaneous abortions and a sudden onset of headache, tinnitus, nausea, and left-sided weakness. The CT scan shows a subarachnoid hemorrhage. These findings suggest a possible diagnosis of immune thrombocytopenia. A mixing study can help to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has a left-sided weakness, headache, nausea, and vomiting. The CT scan shows a right middle cerebral artery infarct. The patient also has thrombocytosis, elevated fibrinogen, prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time, and prolonged thrombin time. These findings suggest a hypercoagulable state. The next step is to perform a mixing study to evaluate for a lupus anticoagulant. Therefore, the answer is: A

MRI/MR angiography of the head and neck. This patient has symptoms and signs suggestive of a cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). A CT scan of the head without contrast may show absent or delayed venous filling, which is a sign of CVST. However, MRI/MR angiography is more sensitive than CT for detecting CVST and is therefore the next best diagnostic step. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of three 1-hour episodes of severe, sharp, penetrating abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant. During these episodes, she has had nausea and vomiting. She has no diarrhea, dysuria, or hematuria and is asymptomatic between episodes. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Seven years ago, she underwent resection of the terminal ileum because of severe Crohn's disease. She is 155 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 130/95 mm Hg. There is mild scleral icterus. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant without guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The stool is brown, and test for occult blood is negative. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count 9,500 mm3
Platelet count 170,000 mm3
Serum
Total bilirubin 4.1 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 348 U/L
AST 187 U/L
ALT 260 U/L
Abdominal ultrasonography shows a normal liver, a common bile duct caliber of 10 mm (normal < 6 mm) and a gallbladder with multiple gallstones and no wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?"
Options: A: Acute hepatitis A	B: Choledocholithiasis	C: Autoimmune hepatitis	D: Cholecystitis	E: Pancreatitis
"
B

The patient has right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Abdominal ultrasonography shows common bile duct dilation and gallbladder stones. These findings suggest choledocholithiasis, which is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has a history of Crohn's disease and has undergone resection of the terminal ileum. She now presents with episodes of severe, sharp, penetrating abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, associated with nausea and vomiting. She has scleral icterus and laboratory studies show elevated bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, AST, and ALT. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a dilated common bile duct and a gallbladder with multiple gallstones but no wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. The most likely cause of these findings is choledocholithiasis, which is the presence of gallstones in the common bile duct. The gallstones can cause obstruction of the bile duct, leading to biliary colic and jaundice. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, nausea, and vomiting. She has mild scleral icterus, and ultrasonography shows a common bile duct caliber of 10 mm and a gallbladder with multiple gallstones. These findings are consistent with choledocholithiasis, which is the presence of gallstones in the common bile duct. Choledocholithiasis can cause intermittent obstruction of the common bile duct, leading to episodes of biliary pain, jaundice, and cholangitis. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has scleral icterus, tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant, and normal bowel sounds. Laboratory studies show elevated total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, AST, and ALT. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a normal liver, a dilated common bile duct, and a gallbladder with multiple gallstones. These findings suggest choledocholithiasis, which is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has a history of Crohn's disease and underwent resection of the terminal ileum. She now has recurrent episodes of severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Laboratory studies show elevated liver enzymes and total bilirubin, and abdominal ultrasonography shows a dilated common bile duct and gallstones. These findings suggest that the patient has choledocholithiasis, which is the presence of gallstones in the common bile duct. The gallstones may have migrated from the gallbladder into the common bile duct, causing obstruction and leading to the patient's symptoms. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 48-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of progressive weakness and shortness of breath. She has had progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough. In addition, she complains of difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair. Her temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Neurologic exam shows 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally. Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation. A faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
Options: A: Muscle biopsy	B: CT scan	C: Pulmonary function tests	D: Serum ANA titer	E: Skin biopsy
A

Serum ANA titer is the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis. Serum ANA titer is a blood test that measures the level of antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) in the blood. ANAs are antibodies that target the body's own cells and tissues. They are found in people with autoimmune diseases, such as lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, and scleroderma. A positive ANA titer indicates that the person may have an autoimmune disease. Therefore, the answer is: D

Serum ANA titer is the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). ANA titers are positive in 95% of patients with SLE, and the titer often correlates with disease activity. The patient has a rash that is consistent with SLE, as well as weakness, shortness of breath, and crackles on lung auscultation. Therefore, the answer is: D

Serum ANA titer is the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in this patient. The patient has symptoms of muscle weakness, shortness of breath, and a rash, which are all common manifestations of SLE. The erythematous rash on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows is suggestive of a butterfly rash, which is a characteristic finding in SLE. A positive ANA titer is a serological marker for SLE and is found in approximately 95% of patients with the disease. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has rash and dry crackles. She presents with a diagnosis of polymyositis with interstitial lung disease. Myositis-specific antibodies are found in 40–50% of patients with dermatomyositis and polymyositis. The serum ANA titer is the test most likely to confirm the diagnosis of polymyositis. Therefore, the answer is: D

Serum ANA titer is the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). ANA titer is a blood test that measures the level of antinuclear antibodies (ANA) in the blood. ANA is a type of autoantibody that is directed against the body's own cell nuclei. In SLE, ANA titer is often elevated and can help to confirm the diagnosis. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?
Options: A: Phosphoprotein p24	B: JAK2 tyrosine kinase	C: E2F transcription factors	D: Phosphoprotein p53	E: Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors
C

Phosphoprotein p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a critical role in the regulation of cell growth and apoptosis. Inactivation of p53 can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation, which is a hallmark of cancer. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a sexually transmitted infection that is associated with the development of cervical cancer. HPV infection can lead to the inactivation of p53, which allows the infected cells to escape apoptosis and proliferate uncontrollably. Therefore, the answer is: D

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the most common risk factor for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) and carcinoma-in-situ. HPV infection can lead to the activation of the E6 and E7 viral oncogenes, which in turn activate cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors, leading to the development of CIN and carcinoma-in-situ. Therefore, the answer is: E

Activation of phosphoprotein p53 best explains the pathogenesis of carcinoma-in-situ. Phosphoprotein p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a role in cell cycle regulation, DNA repair, and apoptosis. Inactivation of p53 can lead to the development of cancer. In carcinoma-in-situ, p53 is often mutated or inactivated, which allows cells with DNA damage to survive and proliferate. Therefore, the answer is: D

Phosphoprotein p53 is activated in response to DNA damage. When DNA is damaged, p53 is phosphorylated and forms a complex with other proteins, such as MDM2, to halt the cell cycle and allow time for DNA repair. If the damage is too severe to be repaired, p53 triggers apoptosis, or cell death. In cancer cells, p53 is often mutated or inactivated, which allows the cells to continue to divide and proliferate, leading to the development of cancer. In the case of cervical cancer, infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) can lead to the inactivation of p53, which allows the development of carcinoma-in-situ and, eventually, invasive cervical cancer. Therefore, the answer is: D

The answer is: D

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the most common sexually transmitted infection. Persistent infection with certain high-risk types of HPV can lead to the development of cervical cancer. The pathogenesis of cervical cancer involves the activation of oncogenes and the inactivation of tumor suppressor genes. The E2F transcription factors are activated by the HPV E7 protein, which leads to the increased expression of cyclin D1 and the inactivation of the retinoblastoma protein (pRb). This results in the release of E2F transcription factors, which promote the expression of genes that are involved in cell cycle progression and proliferation. The p53 tumor suppressor gene is inactivated by the HPV E6 protein, which leads to the loss of p53's ability to induce apoptosis and cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. He had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he complained that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He does not sleep well and wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He does not leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time and psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Short- and long-term memory is impaired. Attention and concentration are impaired. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentration of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference range. He is very concerned about his memory lapses. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
Options: A: Donepezil	B: Fluoxetine	C: Aspirin	D: Ventriculoperitoneal shunt	E: Memantine
B

Question: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent fatigue for 3 months. He works in a factory, but he states that he is able to continue working without any problems. He does not participate in any regular exercise. He had a similar episode 11 months ago that lasted for 3 months and resolved spontaneously. On examination, the patient's body mass index (BMI) is 45 kg/m2, and he has multiple ecchymoses on the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's fatigue?
Options: A: Vitamin B12 deficiency	B: Pernicious anemia	C: Iron deficiency	D: Hypothyroidism	E: Celiac disease
Answer: The patient has a BMI of 45 kg/m2, which is consistent with obesity. Obesity is a risk factor for vitamin B12 deficiency because it can lead to malabsorption of vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause fatigue, ecchymoses, and anemia. Therefore, the answer is: A

Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor which is commonly used in the treatment of mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. It works by increasing the levels of acetylcholine in the brain, which can help to improve cognitive function. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 28-year-old woman has been diagnosed with Parkinson disease which is treated with carbidopa-levodopa. During the past week, she has been experiencing gastrointestinal upset. Her bowel movements have become infrequent and hard to pass. She believes the problem is due to her medication because the symptoms appeared after starting the carbidopa-levodopa. She is otherwise well. She is currently taking only carbidopa-levodopa. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention at this time?
Options: A: Increase the dose of carbidopa-levodopa	B: Switch to amantadine	C: Obtain a gastrointestinal series	D: Add lactulose to the carbidopa-levodopa dose	E: Add a polyethylene glycol laxative to her medication regimen
Answer: Constipation is a common adverse effect of carbidopa-levodopa. The most appropriate intervention at this time is to add a polyethylene glycol laxative to her medication regimen. Polyethylene glycol laxatives are safe and effective for the treatment of constipation in patients with Parkinson disease. They work by increasing the water content of the stool, which makes it softer and easier to pass. Therefore, the answer is: E

Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is used to treat the cognitive symptoms of Alzheimer's disease. It works by increasing the levels of acetylcholine in the brain, a neurotransmitter that is involved in memory and learning. Donepezil has been shown to improve memory and other cognitive functions in patients with Alzheimer's disease. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has progressive memory loss, sleep disturbance, apathy, and impaired daily functioning. He has psychomotor retardation and blunted affect. His short- and long-term memory is impaired, and attention and concentration are impaired as well. These findings suggest dementia. Donepezil is a medication that is used to treat mild to moderate dementia. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that is involved in memory and cognition. By increasing the levels of acetylcholine in the brain, donepezil can help to improve memory and cognitive function. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 54-year-old woman presents with sudden onset, mild vaginal bleeding for the past day. She says she is postmenopausal, and her last menstrual period was 5 years ago. A detailed workup is performed, and several premalignant lesions are found in her uterus. The patient agrees to a hysterectomy. The surgical team decides to use an anesthesia protocol consisting of nitrous oxide, desflurane, and atracurium. Which of the following best describes the role of atracurium in this patient’s anesthesia?
Options: A: It reduces neuron and muscle tissue excitability	B: It increases GABA linked chloride channel opening	C: It acts on the pain centers in the spinal cord and brain	D: It competes with acetylcholine for binding sites in the neuromuscular junction	E: It persistently depolarizes the cholinergic receptors on the motor end plate
D

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that works by competing with acetylcholine for binding sites in the neuromuscular junction. This prevents acetylcholine from binding to its receptors and causing muscle contraction. As a result, atracurium produces skeletal muscle relaxation. Therefore, the answer is: D

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent that works by competing with acetylcholine for binding sites in the neuromuscular junction. This prevents the transmission of nerve impulses to the muscles, resulting in skeletal muscle relaxation. Therefore, the answer is: D

Atracurium is a competitive neuromuscular blocking agent. It competes with acetylcholine for binding sites in the neuromuscular junction, resulting in a blockade of neuromuscular transmission and muscle paralysis. Therefore, the answer is: D

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. It competes with acetylcholine for binding sites in the neuromuscular junction, thereby preventing the depolarization of the motor end plate and the subsequent contraction of skeletal muscle. This results in muscle relaxation and paralysis. Therefore, the answer is: D

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. It works by competitively binding to acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby preventing acetylcholine from binding and causing muscle contraction. This results in flaccid paralysis of skeletal muscles. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 74-year-old man undergoes an open cholecystectomy. Surgery is performed under general anesthesia for which the patient is intubated with an endotracheal tube. Directly following the procedure, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. He is extubated as soon as he showed signs of alertness. Five minutes later, he becomes unresponsive. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. He underwent stenting of the right coronary artery 10 years ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 2 weeks ago for surgery. He drinks one to two beers daily. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 73%. He is put on a non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%. Three minutes later, he is still unresponsive. His arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.32
PCO2 33 mm Hg
PO2 73 mm Hg
HCO3 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 73%
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
Options: A: Perform tracheostomy	B: Continue using the non-rebreather mask	C: Reintubate	D: Close observation only	E: Start BiPAP
C

The patient is unresponsive after extubation following surgery. His arterial blood gas analysis shows hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis. The best next step is to reintubate the patient to secure the airway and provide mechanical ventilation. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient is unresponsive and has a low oxygen saturation despite being on a non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%. Question: A 79-year-old woman presents to her physician complaining of a persistent non-productive cough and dyspnea after contracting a cold in the past month. It is typically acquired by inhalation of arthroconidia, which are airborne spores of the fungus. Symptoms of coccidioidomycosis can range from mild to severe, and can include cough, dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, and chest pain. Diagnosis is based on serologic testing, culture, or histopathology. Treatment is typically with antifungal medications, such as fluconazole or itraconazole. Therefore, the answer is: A

Coccidioidomycosis is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii. It is endemic to the southwestern United States and parts of Mexico and Central and South America. Options: A: Start basal-bolus insulin	B: Continue metformin monotherapy	C: Add a sulfonylurea	D: Add an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor	E: Add a thiazolidinedione
C

The patient has type 2 diabetes and has been started on metformin and lifestyle modifications. His HbA1C is 8.5% and serum glucose is 240 mg/dL. The best next step in this patient’s condition is to add a sulfonylurea. Sulfonylureas are a class of oral medications that are used to treat type 2 diabetes. They work by stimulating the pancreas to release more insulin. They are typically used in combination with other medications, such as metformin, when blood sugar levels are not adequately controlled with monotherapy. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has type 2 diabetes with an HbA1C of 8.5% and a serum glucose of 240 mg/dL, indicating poor glycemic control. The patient is currently on metformin monotherapy, which is not sufficient to achieve glycemic control. The next step in this patient’s condition is to add a second-line agent. Sulfonylureas are a common choice for patients with type 2 diabetes who are not achieving glycemic control with metformin alone. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has poorly controlled type 2 diabetes with an HbA1C of 8.5% and serum glucose of 240 mg/dL. The best next step is to add a second oral agent to metformin. A sulfonylurea is the most appropriate choice because it is effective in lowering blood sugar levels and is generally well-tolerated. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient's HbA1C is 8.5% and serum glucose is 240 mg/dL, which indicates poor glycemic control. The best next step is to intensify his treatment. A sulfonylurea is a good option because it is a relatively inexpensive and effective oral agent that can be added to metformin. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A man is brought into the emergency department by the police department. The officer state that the man has been arrested multiple times for public alcohol intoxication, but recently became homeless. On exam, the man is behaving erratically. His vitals are all within normal limits. He appears confused and has a slurred speech. On gait exam, the patient is ataxic and cannot stand without support for more than a few seconds. Labs return with the following values: Na 140, K 4, Cl 106, BUN 8, Cr 2. His ABG has pH 7.3, PaCO2 13mm, PaO2 130mm, HCO3 7. His urinalysis is shown in Figure 1. Blood salicylate levels return as normal. While you await other diagnostic tests, which of the following should be administered next to treat this patient?
Options: A: Ethanol	B: Naltrexone	C: Naloxone	D: Flumazenil	E: Fomepizole
E

The patient has altered mental status, slurred speech, ataxia, and hyponatremia. His urine has elevated ketones. These findings suggest alcohol withdrawal. The initial treatment of alcohol withdrawal is benzodiazepines. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has altered mental status and ataxia, which are signs of alcohol intoxication. The urinalysis shows a large number of ketone bodies, which suggests that the patient is also in a state of ketoacidosis. The next step in management is to administer thiamine to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy, which is a serious neurological condition that can occur in patients with chronic alcohol abuse. Thiamine is a cofactor for several enzymes involved in glucose metabolism, and its deficiency can lead to the development of Wernicke encephalopathy. Therefore, the answer is: Fomepizole

Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist. It is used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines, such as confusion, slurred speech, and ataxia. In this case, the patient is likely intoxicated with alcohol and benzodiazepines. Naloxone is used to reverse the effects of opioids, which is not the case here. Ethanol and naltrexone are used to treat alcohol dependence, which is not the case here. Fomepizole is used to treat methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, which is not the case here. Therefore, the answer is: D

Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that can be used to treat opioid toxicity. It is not typically used to treat alcohol intoxication. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that can be used to treat opioid toxicity. It is also not typically used to treat alcohol intoxication. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist that can be used to treat benzodiazepine toxicity. It is not typically used to treat alcohol intoxication. Fomepizole is an antidote for ethylene glycol and methanol poisoning. It is not typically used to treat alcohol intoxication. Therefore, the answer is: Ethanol is a depressant, but it can be used to treat alcohol intoxication. Ethanol competitively inhibits the effects of alcohol on the central nervous system. This can help to reduce the severity of the patient's symptoms. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient is intoxicated with methanol, evidenced by the elevated anion gap, decreased bicarbonate, low serum osmolality, and the presence of formic acid on urinalysis. Treatment should focus on correcting the anion gap and minimizing the formation of toxic metabolites. Fomepizole is the antidote of choice for methanol poisoning and should be administered next. Therefore, the answer is: E

Question: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty discarding items in her home. She says that the accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room makes regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult. Her behavior started when she was in high school. She feels anxious when she tries to discard her possessions and her husband tries to clean and organize the home. This behavior frustrates her because most of the items she saves have little emotional or monetary value. She reports that there has been no improvement despite attending cognitive behavioral therapy sessions for the past 6 months. She now feels that her behavior is “taking over” her life. She does not drink, smoke, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg. On mental status examination, she is calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time. Her mood is depressed; her speech is organized, logical, and coherent; and there are no psychotic symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Options: A: Atomoxetine	B: Fluoxetine	C: Lamotrigine	D: Buspirone	E: Methylphenidate
B

The most appropriate next step in management is fluoxetine. Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is effective in the treatment of hoarding disorder. It is generally well-tolerated and has a low risk of side effects. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has difficulty discarding items in her home, feels anxious when she tries to discard possessions, and her behavior frustrates her. There is no history of substance abuse or psychiatric disorders. The diagnosis is hoarding disorder. The next step is to start fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), which is effective in treating hoarding disorder. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has symptoms of hoarding disorder, which is characterized by persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions, regardless of their actual value. This behavior causes significant distress or impairment in functioning. The patient has tried cognitive behavioral therapy, but it has not been effective. Therefore, the next step in management is to consider pharmacotherapy. Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that has been shown to be effective in treating hoarding disorder. Therefore, the answer is: B

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant that is commonly used for the treatment of hoarders. It is effective in reducing the severity of symptoms and improving quality of life. Therefore, the answer is: B

The patient has difficulty discarding items in her home, which has become a source of distress for her and her husband. She has also experienced anxiety and depression. The most appropriate next step in management is to start fluoxetine because it is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that has been shown to be effective in the treatment of hoarding disorder. Therefore, the answer is: B.

Question: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of a 6-month history of worsening short-term memory deficits and social withdrawal. Treatment with galantamine is initiated. Two weeks later, the patient develops vomiting, mild crampy abdominal pain, and watery, nonbloody diarrhea. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
Options: A: Bethanechol	B: Metoclopramide	C: Loperamide	D: Atropine	E: Oxybutynin
D

Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist that is used to treat nausea and vomiting. It is effective in treating the vomiting associated with galantamine therapy. Loperamide is an opioid that is used to treat diarrhea. It can be used to treat the diarrhea associated with galantamine therapy, but it may also cause constipation. Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that is used to treat diarrhea. It can be used to treat the diarrhea associated with galantamine therapy, but it may also cause dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention. Bethanechol is a cholinergic drug that is used to treat urinary retention. It is not indicated for the treatment of vomiting or diarrhea. Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic drug that is used to treat urinary incontinence. It is not indicated for the treatment of vomiting or diarrhea. Therefore, the answer is: B

Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist that increases the tone and amplitude of gastric and intestinal contractions. It is used to treat gastrointestinal motility disorders, including nausea and vomiting. In this patient, metoclopramide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for the treatment of vomiting. Therefore, the answer is: B

Metoclopramide is an antidopaminergic agent that can be used to treat nausea and vomiting. It is commonly used in the treatment of nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy, radiation therapy, surgery, or other medical conditions. Metoclopramide works by blocking dopamine receptors in the central nervous system and the gastrointestinal tract. This can help to reduce nausea and vomiting and improve gastric emptying. Therefore, the answer is: B

Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist that increases gastrointestinal motility and decreases nausea and vomiting. It is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient because it can help to relieve the patient's vomiting and diarrhea, which are likely caused by the side effects of galantamine. Therefore, the answer is: B

Metoclopramide is a dopamine antagonist that increases gastrointestinal motility and blocks central dopamine receptors, thereby reducing nausea and vomiting. It is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient because it can help to relieve the vomiting and diarrhea that are side effects of galantamine. Bethanechol and atropine are both cholinergic drugs that can also increase gastrointestinal motility, but they are less effective than metoclopramide at reducing nausea and vomiting. Loperamide is an opioid agonist that slows gastrointestinal motility and can be used to treat diarrhea, but it is not effective at reducing nausea and vomiting. Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic drug that can be used to treat urinary incontinence, but it is not effective at reducing nausea and vomiting. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by ambulance after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He was driving a motorcycle and collided with a bus. The EMT personnel found the patient alert with anterograde amnesia for the several minutes preceding the accident. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is drowsy but follows commands. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. The remainder of the initial examination is unremarkable. While the patient is being transferred to observation, his level of consciousness acutely declines. Repeat vital signs are significant for a blood pressure of 190/110 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination now shows a fixed and dilated left pupil with no pupillary light reflex. A noncontrast CT of the head is performed and is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
Options: A: Tearing of the middle meningeal artery	B: Dural arteriovenous fistula	C: Tearing of bridging veins	D: Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm	E: Arteriovenous malformation
A

The patient has a subdural hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. Subdural hematomas are usually caused by trauma, such as a motor vehicle collision. The symptoms of a subdural hematoma can vary depending on the size and location of the hematoma. In this case, the patient has a fixed and dilated left pupil, which is a sign of increased intracranial pressure. The most likely etiology of this patient's condition is tearing of bridging veins. Bridging veins are small veins that connect the superficial and deep venous systems of the brain. When these veins are torn, blood can leak into the subdural space and form a subdural hematoma. Therefore, the answer is: C

The image shows a left-sided epidural hematoma. The most likely etiology of this patient’s condition is tearing of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery that supplies blood to the dura mater. It is commonly injured in head trauma, resulting in an epidural hematoma. Epidural hematomas are characterized by a rapidly expanding collection of blood between the dura mater and the skull. They can cause a rapid decline in consciousness and death if not promptly treated. Therefore, the answer is: A

The image shows a CT scan of the head showing a large epidural hematoma on the left side. This is most likely due to tearing of the middle meningeal artery, which is a common cause of epidural hematomas. The middle meningeal artery is located between the skull and the dura mater, and it can be torn by a blow to the head. The tearing of the artery causes blood to accumulate between the skull and the dura mater, which can lead to increased intracranial pressure and decreased level of consciousness. Therefore, the answer is: A

The noncontrast CT of the head shows a large acute left epidural hematoma. A left epidural hematoma is most likely due to tearing of the middle meningeal artery. This artery is located in the middle cranial fossa and can be torn during head trauma. This can lead to the formation of an extradural hematoma, which can compress the brain and cause neurological symptoms. Therefore, the answer is: A

A noncontrast CT scan of the head demonstrates extra-axial hyperdensity in the right middle cranial fossa, consistent with an acute subdural hematoma. Tearing of the middle meningeal artery is the most likely etiology of this patient's condition. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: Background:
Some patients with severe asthma have frequent exacerbations associated with persistent eosinophilic inflammation despite continuous treatment with high-dose inhaled glucocorticoids with or without oral glucocorticoids.
Methods:
In this randomized, double-blind clinical trial we assigned 576 patients with recurrent asthma exacerbations and evidence of eosinophilic inflammation despite high doses of inhaled glucocorticoids to one of three study groups. Patients were assigned to receive mepolizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody against interleukin-5, which was administered as either a 75-mg intravenous dose or a 100-mg subcutaneous dose or placebo every 4 weeks for 32 weeks. The primary outcome was the rate of exacerbations. Other outcomes included the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and scores on the St. George’s Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) and the 5-item Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ-5).
Results:
The rate of exacerbations was reduced by 47% (95% confidence interval [CI], 29 to 61) among patients receiving intravenous mepolizumab and by 53% (95% CI, 37 to 65) among those receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab, as compared with those receiving placebo (p<0.001 for both comparisons). Exacerbations necessitating an emergency department visit or hospitalization were reduced by 32% in the group receiving intravenous mepolizumab and by 61% in the group receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab. At week 32, the mean increase from baseline in FEV1 was 100 ml greater in patients receiving intravenous mepolizumab than in those receiving placebo (p=0.02) and 98 ml greater in patients receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab than in those receiving placebo (p=0.03). The improvement from baseline in the SGRQ score was 6.4 points and 7.0 points greater in the intravenous and subcutaneous mepolizumab groups, respectively than in the placebo group, and the improvement in the ACQ-5 score was 0.42 points and 0.44 points greater in the two mepolizumab groups, respectively than in the placebo group (p<0.001 for all comparisons).
Conclusions:
Mepolizumab administered either intravenously or subcutaneously significantly reduced asthma exacerbations and was associated with improvements in markers of asthma control.
Given the original research abstract above, which of the following would be true if the authors had inadvertently encountered a type 1 error?
Options: A: A type 1 error means the study is not significantly powered to detect a true difference between study groups.	B: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error.	C: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is false, yet is accepted in error.	D: A type 1 error is a beta (β) error and is usually 0.1 or 0.2.	E: A type 1 error is dependent on the confidence interval of a study.
B
B: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error.

B: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error.

A type 1 error is the rejection of a true null hypothesis. This means that the study results are statistically significant, but the difference between the study groups is actually due to chance. In this case, the authors would have concluded that mepolizumab was effective in reducing asthma exacerbations, when in reality it was not. Therefore, the answer is: B

B: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error.
A type 1 error is also known as a false positive. It occurs when a researcher rejects the null hypothesis when it is actually true. In other words, the researcher finds a significant result when there is no real effect. This can happen due to chance or because the researcher made a mistake in the design or execution of the study.

B: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error.

If the authors had inadvertently encountered a type 1 error, it means that they rejected the null hypothesis when it was actually true. This means that they concluded that there was a significant difference between the study groups when, in reality, there was not.

A type 1 error is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true. This error can occur when the study is not significantly powered to detect a true difference between study groups (option A), but this is not the only cause of a type 1 error.

A type 1 error is not a beta (β) error (option D) and is not dependent on the confidence interval of a study (option E).

A type 1 error is distinct from a type 2 error, which occurs when the null hypothesis is false but is accepted in error.

B: A type 1 error occurs when the null hypothesis is true but is rejected in error. A type 1 error is also known as a false positive. It occurs when a researcher incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis when it is actually true. This can happen when the data is not truly statistically significant, but the researcher concludes that it is. In this case, the authors would have concluded that mepolizumab was effective in reducing asthma exacerbations when it was not. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss. He is a vegetarian. The patient’s family says that he had been high functioning but has had significant behavioral changes over the past year. The patient denies any smoking history, alcohol consumption, or illicit drug use. No significant family history. His vital signs include: blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes, pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉). Physical examination reveals a poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man. He is irritable, paranoid, and delusional but denies any hallucinations. An unstable, wide-based ataxic gait is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following:
Hb 6.1 g/dL
MCV 109 fL
Platelets 90,0000/mm3
Total count 3,000/mm3
Reticulocyte count 0.8%
A peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
 
Options: A: Hypothyroidism	B: Folate deficiency	C: Vitamin B12 deficiency	D: Parvovirus infection	E: Pernicious anemia
C

The patient has a history of fatigue, weight loss, anemia, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. The peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. These findings are consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 is necessary for the synthesis of DNA and the maturation of red blood cells. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to anemia, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is pernicious anemia, an autoimmune disorder in which the body attacks the cells in the stomach that produce intrinsic factor. Intrinsic factor is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 from the gastrointestinal tract. Therefore, the answer is: E

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a condition that can cause a variety of symptoms, including fatigue, weakness, weight loss, and neurological problems. In this patient, the most likely cause of the vitamin B12 deficiency is pernicious anemia, an autoimmune condition in which the body attacks the cells in the stomach that produce intrinsic factor, a protein that is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12. The patient has a history of weight loss, fatigue, and neurological problems, and the peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils, which is a classic sign of vitamin B12 deficiency. Therefore, the answer is: E

Vitamin B12 deficiency is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to macrocytic anemia, which is characterized by abnormally large red blood cells. The patient has a low hemoglobin level, a high MCV, and a low reticulocyte count, which are all consistent with macrocytic anemia. The patient also has hypersegmented neutrophils, which is another sign of vitamin B12 deficiency. The patient is a vegetarian, which puts him at risk for vitamin B12 deficiency. Therefore, the answer is: C

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a common cause of megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by large, immature red blood cells. Vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause neurological symptoms, such as neuropathy, dementia, and psychiatric disturbances. The patient in this case has megaloblastic anemia, neurological symptoms, and a history of weight loss and fatigue. The peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils, which is another sign of vitamin B12 deficiency. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has a history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss. He is a vegetarian. His vital signs include: blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes, pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉). Physical examination reveals a poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man. He is irritable, paranoid, and delusional but denies any hallucinations. An unstable, wide-based ataxic gait is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following: Hb 6.1 g/dL, MCV 109 fL, Platelets 90,0000/mm3, Total count 3,000/mm3, Reticulocyte count 0.8% and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 16-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency room with acute vomiting and abdominal pain that began earlier today. His parents say that the boy was doing well until two days ago when he told them that he was feeling unwell. He has diabetes and takes insulin but stopped taking it when he began to feel poorly two days ago. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respirations are shallow and rapid with a rate of 33/min, pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 101/68 mm Hg. He appears severely dehydrated, showing signs of fatigue, and poor skin turgor. His breath has a fruity smell to it. His blood glucose level is 691 mg/dL. Blood is drawn for labs and the results are given below:
Serum:  
  pH: 7.21
  pCO2: 32 mm HG
  HCO 3-: 15.2 mEq/L
Sodium: 122 mEq/L
Potassium: 5.8 mEq/L
Urinalysis is positive for ketone bodies. What is the most appropriate immediate step in the management of this patient?
Options: A: Administer IV fluids and insulin	B: Administer IV antibiotics	C: Administer IV fluids with oral antidiabetic medications	D: Administer IV bicarbonate	E: Administer potassium and magnesium
A

The patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body does not have enough insulin. The patient has a high blood glucose level, low blood pH, low bicarbonate level, and positive urine ketones. The most appropriate immediate step in the management of this patient is to administer IV fluids, insulin, and electrolyte supplements (such as potassium and magnesium). Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is a medical emergency. The most appropriate immediate step is to administer IV fluids and insulin. This will help to correct the dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and high blood glucose levels. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has a low pH, elevated pCO2, and low bicarbonate level. This is consistent with metabolic acidosis. The fruity smell of the breath suggests ketoacidosis, which is a type of metabolic acidosis caused by elevated levels of ketones. The patient also has hyperglycemia and a positive urine ketone test, which further supports the diagnosis of ketoacidosis. The most appropriate immediate step in the management of this patient is to administer IV fluids and insulin. IV fluids will help to correct the dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. Insulin will help to lower the blood glucose level and reduce the production of ketones. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has diabetic ketoacidosis, which is a life-threatening complication of diabetes that occurs when the body does not have enough insulin. The patient has hyperglycemia, ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis. The most appropriate immediate step in the management of this patient is to administer IV fluids and insulin to correct the fluid and electrolyte imbalances and to lower the blood glucose level. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is a life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus characterized by severe hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and dehydration. The patient has a history of diabetes, stopped taking insulin when he began to feel poorly two days ago, and now presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, and dehydration. His blood glucose level is 691 mg/dL, and his breath has a fruity smell. His laboratory studies show metabolic acidosis (pH 7.21, pCO2 32 mm Hg, HCO3- 15.2 mEq/L) and hyperkalemia (5.8 mEq/L). The most appropriate immediate step in the management of this patient is to administer IV fluids and insulin. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 45-year-old mechanic presents to the emergency department complaining of acute-onset shortness of breath while repairing a plowing tractor for his neighbor. The patient denies having any history of asthma or respiratory symptoms, and does not smoke. His temperature is 99.8°F (37.7°C), pulse is 65/min, blood pressure is 126/86 mmHg, and respirations are 20/min. His oxygen saturation is 97%. On exam, he is pale and diaphoretic. His pupils are contracted. Diffuse wheezes are noted in all lung fields. What is the best treatment for his condition?
Options: A: Intubation	B: Succinylcholine	C: Inhaled ipratropium and oxygen	D: Atropine and pralidoxime	E: Inhaled albuterol and oxygen
D

The patient has acute-onset shortness of breath, wheezing, and is in respiratory distress. He does not have a history of asthma or respiratory symptoms. He is pale, diaphoretic, and has contracted pupils. These findings are suggestive of organophosphate poisoning. The best treatment is atropine and pralidoxime. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has acute-onset shortness of breath, wheezes in all lung fields, and a normal oxygen saturation. The best treatment for his condition is inhaled albuterol and oxygen. Albuterol is a beta-2 agonist that relaxes the smooth muscle in the airways, which can help to improve airflow. Oxygen can help to improve oxygen saturation and relieve shortness of breath. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient has acute-onset shortness of breath, wheezing, and is diaphoretic. He denies a history of asthma or respiratory symptoms, and does not smoke. This suggests a possible allergic reaction to an inhaled substance. The best treatment for his condition is inhaled albuterol and oxygen. Albuterol is a bronchodilator that helps to open the airways, and oxygen will help to improve his oxygen saturation. Therefore, the answer is: E

Inhaled albuterol and oxygen are the best treatment for this patient's condition. The patient has acute-onset shortness of breath, wheezing, and diaphoresis, which are all signs of an asthma attack. Inhaled albuterol is a bronchodilator that helps to open up the airways, and oxygen can help to improve oxygenation. Therefore, the answer is: E

The patient has acute-onset shortness of breath with diffuse wheezes in all lung fields. He is pale, diaphoretic, and has contracted pupils. These findings suggest cholinergic hyperstimulation, which can be caused by organophosphate poisoning. The best treatment for organophosphate poisoning is atropine and pralidoxime. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 12-year-old girl is brought to your psychiatry office by her parents, who are concerned that she has not made any friends since starting middle school last year. The girl tells you that she gets nervous around other children, as she cannot tell what they are feeling, when they are joking, or what she has in common with them. Her teachers describe her as “easily distracted” and “easily upset by change.” When asked about her hobbies and interests, she states that “marine biology” is her only interest and gives you a 15-minute unsolicited explanation of how to identify different penguin species. Mental status exam is notable for intense eye contact, flat affect, and concrete thought process. Which of the following is true regarding this child’s disorder?
Options: A: Boys are more commonly affected than girls	B: Impaired attention is a key feature of the disorder	C: Intellectual disability is a key feature of the disorder	D: It is usually associated with a family history of schizophrenia	E: Typical age of onset is 3-5 years of age
A
Boys are more commonly affected than girls is true regarding the child's disorder. Therefore, the answer is: A

The child most likely has autism spectrum disorder (ASD). ASD is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects social and communication skills. Girls are less commonly affected than boys. Impaired attention is not a key feature of ASD. Intellectual disability is not a key feature of ASD. It is not usually associated with a family history of schizophrenia. Typical age of onset is 3-5 years of age. Therefore, the answer is: E

Boys are more commonly affected than girls. This disorder typically presents during early development, with a male preponderance. Symptoms usually manifest before age 3, but the full syndrome may not be evident until the child is older. Therefore, the answer is: A

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, as well as restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior. The cause of ASD is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. ASD is more common in boys than girls, and it usually begins in early childhood. Children with ASD may have difficulty understanding social cues, making friends, and communicating with others. They may also have difficulty with change and may exhibit repetitive behaviors, such as rocking back and forth or flapping their hands. Treatment for ASD typically involves a combination of behavioral therapy, medication, and educational support. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient displays a concrete thought process, restricted interests, and difficulty with social interactions. These symptoms are consistent with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), which is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by social and communication deficits, as well as restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior. Boys are more commonly affected than girls, and the disorder is usually not associated with intellectual disability or a family history of schizophrenia. Impaired attention is not a key feature of ASD, and the typical age of onset is 3-5 years of age. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to a pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of frequent bed wetting during the night. A detailed history reveals that there has been no history of urinary incontinence during the day since the boy was 4 years of age, but that he has never been dry at night continuously for 1 week. There is no history of urinary tract infections, urgency, frequency, or hesitancy. On physical examination, the boy’s vital signs are stable. His neurologic and abdominal examinations are completely normal. His laboratory investigations are as follows:
Urine-specific gravity (first-morning sample) 1.035

Question: A 47-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of her right hand. Question: A 5-year-old Syrian immigrant and her family present for an immigration physical. Question: A 42-year-old man presents to your office complaining of right-sided facial swelling that has progressively worsened over the last month after returning from a trip to India. Question: A 36-year-old nursing home worker presents to the clinic with the complaints of breathlessness, cough, and night sweats for the past 2 months. Rifampin is a potent inducer of CYP3A4, an enzyme that metabolizes many drugs. This can lead to decreased levels of contraceptive hormones in the bloodstream, making them less effective at preventing pregnancy. Estrogens undergo enterohepatic circulation, which is a process by which they are absorbed from the gut, metabolized by the liver, and then reabsorbed into the gut. Rifampin alters the normal gastrointestinal flora, which can lead to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens, resulting in lower levels of estrogen in the bloodstream and potentially reducing the effectiveness of combination oral contraceptive pills. Isoniazid, a first-line anti-tuberculosis medication, inhibits ferrochelatase, an enzyme necessary for the incorporation of iron into protoporphyrin IX. Question: A 10-year-old girl is brought to a clinic by her parents after 1 week of difficulty breathing, dry cough, and low-grade fevers. Question: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a post-natal visit. She was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 25-year-old woman via an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother reports that prenatal screening revealed no developmental abnormalities and that the baby has been gaining weight, feeding, stooling, and urinating appropriately. Which of the following is true regarding the baby’s reproductive system at this time?
Options: A: The baby has not yet developed oocytes	B: The baby’s oocytes are arrested in prophase	C: The baby’s oocytes are arrested in metaphase	D: The baby’s oocytes are arrested in interphase	E: The baby’s oocytes are fully matured
B
All female germ cells are assembled prior to birth and are arrested in prophase of the first meiotic division until puberty. Therefore, the answer is: B

The baby has oocytes that are arrested in prophase. During fetal development, the ovaries contain millions of oogonia, which are immature germ cells. These oogonia begin to divide and differentiate into primary oocytes, which then arrest in prophase of the first meiotic division. This arrest is maintained until puberty, when the oocytes complete meiosis and become mature eggs. Therefore, the answer is: B

The baby’s oocytes are arrested in prophase. At the time of birth, all of the baby's oocytes are arrested in prophase I of meiosis. This means that they have not yet completed the first meiotic division. The oocytes will remain arrested in prophase I until puberty, when they will begin to mature. Therefore, the answer is: B

The baby's oocytes are arrested in prophase. During fetal development, the ovaries contain oogonia, which are immature germ cells. These oogonia undergo mitosis to produce primary oocytes, which then enter meiosis and arrest at the prophase I stage. This arrest is maintained until puberty, when the oocytes resume meiosis and complete maturation. Therefore, the answer is: B

The baby's oocytes are arrested in prophase. At birth, the baby's ovaries contain approximately 1–2 million oocytes, which are arrested in the first stage of prophase of the first meiotic division. These oocytes will remain arrested until puberty, when they will begin to mature in response to the rise in gonadotropin levels. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 37-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of vaginal bleeding and dull suprapubic pain for 3 hours. This procedure is typically performed under general anesthesia. Therefore, the answer is: D

The most appropriate next step in management is dilation and curettage (D&C), which is a procedure in which the cervix is dilated and the contents of the uterus are scraped out. This is done to remove the retained products of conception and to prevent infection. Therefore, the answer is: D

The most appropriate next step in management is dilation and curettage because the patient has an incomplete spontaneous abortion, which is characterized by vaginal bleeding and pain. A dilatation and curettage is a surgical procedure in which the cervix is dilated and the contents of the uterus are removed. This is the most effective way to treat an incomplete spontaneous abortion and prevent infection. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient has a dilated cervical os and an embryo with no fetal cardiac activity. This is consistent with a missed abortion. The most appropriate next step in management is dilation and curettage to remove the products of conception. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 61-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with chest pain. He states that he is worried about his heart, as his father died at age 62 from a heart attack.
